content: Have military uniform standards changed? I have recently noticed many military personnel in my area wearing their uniforms in a very different standard than we did when I was active duty and even reserve. Yesterday my wife and I were eating lunch in a local restaurant and three male E-5’s walked in. I noticed them from the parking lot and none wore a cover outside. There was no trace of any pleats, crease, or starch on any of the uniforms. One fellow even had his trousers unbloused. They appeared clean and didn’t look like they had come from any work or training site. I know they can’t do much with the boots because they are suede but overall these guys looked bad.
reply: Have military uniform standards changed? I have recently noticed many military personnel in my area wearing their uniforms in a very different standard than we did when I was active duty and even reserve. Yesterday my wife and I were eating lunch in a local restaurant and three male E-5’s walked in. I noticed them from the parking lot and none wore a cover outside. There was no trace of any pleats, crease, or starch on any of the uniforms. One fellow even had his trousers unbloused. They appeared clean and didn’t look like they had come from any work or training site. I know they can’t do much with the boots because they are suede but overall these guys looked bad.
title: Have uniform standards changed?

title: Have uniform standards changed?

content: The starch is gone, because through night vision gear, it shows up white. Before the Army went with the "Bag of Potatoes" look, I can remember "breaking starch" every morning when I was an Assistant Drill Sergeant. I had 14 sets of fatigues and at least 5 sets were in the laundry at any one time getting the Military Creases glazed in. Sometimes they would come back with "Starch icecicles" hanging down two or three inches from the cuffs. Shoving a foot down through the pantleg and a fist through the sleeves was almost a workout in and of itself... Those days are definitely long gone!! Wandering and Wondering
reply: The starch is gone, because through night vision gear, it shows up white. content: They took away my old ODs and my Ike jacket, and my Khakis. Then you ask if uniform standards have changed. Darn right, they have changed and I have not liked it at all. Take a look at how they dressed to meet the POTUS. I never thought it possible that anything other than class A's would be the appropriate uniform to meet the president. Oh, the little girl in front is my daughter. God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

content: We've talked about this in the Army forum numerous times. I thought the BDU's were sharp, and offered some concealment. The new ones stick out like a hunters orange vest. content: I remember the days of starched uniforms, khakis and fatigues, which really looked great until you put them on. When there was an in-ranks inspection where the uniform was khakis or fatigues we would go to breakfast in one uniform then change into another for the inspection. We did not sit down because as soon as you did the uniform looked like crap.
reply: I remember the days of starched uniforms, khakis and fatigues, which really looked great until you put them on.
